metadata.title: On heat transfer in the presence of nano-sized particles suspended in a magnetized rotatory flow field

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Case Studies in Thermal Engineering
journal homepage: www.elsevier.com/locate/csite
On heat transfer in the presence of nano-sized particles suspended in a magnetized rotatory flow field
Khalil Ur Rehmana, Iqra Shahzadia, M.Y. Malikb, Qasem M. Al-Mdallalc,∗, Mostafa Zahrid
aDepartment of Mathematics, Air University, PAF Complex E-9, Islamabad 44000, Pakistan bDepartment of Mathematics, College of Sciences, King Khalid University, Abha 61413, Saudi Arabia cDepartment of Mathematical Sciences, United Arab Emirates University, P.O. Box 15551, Al Ain, Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates dDepartment of Mathematics, Research Group MASEP, College of Sciences, University of Sharjah, 27272, United Arab Emirates
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: Casson fluid model Rotating rigid disk Heat transfer Heat generation/absorption Nanoparticles
A B S T R A C T
In this paper, the rotatory non-Newtonian fluid flow subject to rigid disk is debated. The Casson fluid is used as a non-Newtonian fluid model and the fluid is equipped above the rigid disk. The rotatory flow field is interacted with an applied magnetic field. The heat transfer aspects are evaluated in the presence of heat source/sink. Further, the nanosized particles are suspended in the flow regime. The physical statement is mathematically controlled in terms of partial differential equations. The numerical method named shooting method is utilized in this analysis. The involved flow controlling parameters includes the Casson fluid parameter, magnetic field parameter, heat generation parameter, heat absorption parameter, thermophoresis parameter, Brownian motion parameter and Lewis number. The impact of these parameters are examined on the Casson fluid velocities, temperature and concentration. It is noticed that the both radial and tangential velocities are supressed in the magnetized rotatory flow field as compared to nonmagnetized rotatory flow field. The Casson fluid temperature enhances towards higher values of thermophoresis and heat generation parameters. The results are compared with an existing work which yields the surety of adopted computational algorithm.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
The study of heat transfer subject to fluid flows received considerable attention due huge applications in the field of engineering and industrial frame work. The transfer of heat is possible for both the Newtonian and non-Newtonian fluids. When stress is directly proportional to strain rate than the fluid is termed as Newtonian fluid. Alternatively, fluid for which the Newtonian's law of viscosity holds is called Newtonian fluid. The most common examples as a Newtonian fluid are air, water, gasoline, oil, alcohol and even glycerin to mention just a few. Owing the importance of Newtonian fluids various researchers contributed their findings. One can assessed the recent detail in this direction in Refs. [1–3]. Opposite is the case with non-Newtonian fluid that is the fluids in which the stress is not directly proportional to strain rate. Alternatively, those fluids in which the Newtonians law of viscosity does not holds are termed as non-Newtonian fluids. The examples in this direction includes colloids, gels, suspensions and slurries to mention just a few. To investigate the flow properties of non-Newtonian fluid flows researchers proposed various non-Newtonian fluid models and one can study the non-Newtonian fluids by developing analogue with these models. The dominant models in this direction are Oldroyd-A
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.csite.2019.100457 Received 3 April 2019; Received in revised form 19 April 2019; Accepted 21 April 2019
∗ Corresponding author. E-mail address: q.almdallal@uaeu.ac.ae (Q.M. Al-Mdallal).
Case Studies in Thermal Engineering 14 (2019) 100457
Available online 22 April 2019 2214-157X/ © 2019 The Authors. Published by Elsevier Ltd. This is an open access article under the CC BY license (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/BY/4.0/).
T
fluid model, Oldroyd-B fluid model, Oldroyd-8 constants fluid model, Jeffery fluid model, Maxwell fluid model, Casson fluid model, Burgers fluid model, Generalized fluid model, Bingham Herschel–Bulkley fluid model, Seely fluid model, Carreau fluid model, Carreau–Yasuda fluid model, Sisko fluid model, Eyring fluid model, Cross fluid model, Ellis fluid model, Williamson fluid model and tangent hyperbolic fluid model. Out of these the Casson fluid model claims various advantages over rest of the non-Newtonian fluid models. It is accepted to narrate the characteristics of juices, chocolates, sauces and for bio fluids like blood. The recent developments on Casson fluid towards various configurations can be assessed in Refs. [4–12]. The fluid flow having interaction with magnetic field is termed as magnetohydrodynamic (MHD) study. Electrolytes, salt water, liquid metals and plasmas are the typical examples of magneto-fluids. Alfven [13] was the first one who identified the role of magnetic interaction. On this idea he was awarded with Nobel Prize in 1970. The idea was extended and researchers used mathematical model to report magnetic field properties towards both Newtonian and non-Newtonian fluid flows. The study was conducted by coupling the Maxwell's equations subject to electromagnetism with Navier-Stokes equations from the field of fluid science. The magnetized flow field properties for boundary layer fluid flow subject to stretched surface was investigated by Pavlov [14]. In this attempt the transverse magnetic field is taken. The exact solution was proposed for the governing viscous fluid flow narrating equations. Chakrabarti and Gupta [15] extended the work presented in Ref. [14]. They considered fluid flow over a flat surface and magnetic field was taken perpendicular to the flow direction. The flow regime was further taken with heat transfer properties. The flow field was controlled mathematically. The similarity solution was proposed and discussed by means of graphs and tables. It was claimed that the presented problem possessed some applications in the field of polymer technology and metallurgy. The polymer area includes preparation of plastic sheets and the metallurgical processes includes the continuous strips cooling or filaments by drawing them through a quiescent fluid. The role of magnetic towards non-Newtonian fluid models was examined like Andersson et al. [16] considered interaction of the magnetic field with the power-law fluid. The flow of power law fluid was achieved by stretched surface. The obtained mathematical problem was solved numerically. Results are shared with the aid of graphs and tables. Since than many researchers reports the interaction of both the Newtonian and non-Newtonian fluid models with the applied magnetic field in various configurations. One can assessed the recent developments in this direction in Refs. [17–45].
The current pagination contains numerical investigation on the magnetized rotatory non-Newtonian fluid flow over a rigid disk. The article is design in such a way: the limited literature assessment is provided in Section-1 while the mathematical formulation is presented in Section-2. The solution is obtained by shooting method and the computational directory in this direction is debated in Section-3. The impact of involved flow controlling parameters are examined and the detail analysis is provided in Section-4. The Section-5 is devoted for results validation. Lastly, the concluding outcomes are itemized as a Section-6.

sections.heading: 2. Problem formulation
sections.text:
The rigid rotating disk is considered. The non-Newtonian fluid is taken above the rigid disk and it is rotating with constant frequency. The non-Newtonian fluid used is named as Casson fluid. Further, the rotatory fluid flow regime is interacted with normally applied magnetic field. The nanosized particles are suspended in the rotatory fluid flow regime. The heat transfer properties are carried with heat source and sink effects. The whole theoretical set-up is mathematically controlled by means of partial differential equations. By using boundary layer approximation the ultimate system of differential equations can be written as:

sections.heading: 3. Computational outline
sections.text:
The system given by Eqs. 9–13 is coupled system in terms of ordinary differential equations. It is almost impossible to find exact to interpret the rotatory Casson fluid flow regime. The possible choice we have the shooting method along with Runge-Kutta scheme, see Refs. [36–47]. It is important to note that for utilizing the shooting method we must have first order differential system therefore to achieve the basic requirement the following exercise is carried.

sections.heading: 4. Results and discussion
sections.text:
We have considered the Casson fluid towards rigid rotatory disk. The flow regime is further manifested with applied magnetic field. The nanosized particles are suspended in the rotatory flow field. The physical concern is mathematically attained in terms of partial differential equations, see Eqs. (1)–(7). Particularly, the Eq. (1) is equation of continuity reflecting conservation of mass while Eqs. (2)–(4) are the equations of momentum in the presence of applied magnetic field and such equations corresponds the law of conservation of momentum. The energy equation in the presence of heat generation and absorption is given in Eq. (5) which corresponds the law of conservation of energy. The Eq. (6) is the equation of concentration. The boundary constraints having velocity slip is given in Eq. (7). To achieve the equivalent flow narrating differential system we have used the set of variables given in Eq. (8). The system given in Eqs. 9–13 is equivalent to system given in Eqs. (2)–(7). The possible appeared flow controlling parameters are the magnetic field parameter γ( ), Casson fluid parameter λ( ), Prandtl number (Pr), thermophoresis parameter N( )T , heat generation parameter +H( ), heat absorption parameter −H( ), Brownian motion parameter N( )B , Lewis number Le( )and the velocity slip parameter β( ). The mathematical definition to each parameter is defined in Eq. (14). The surface quantities are mathematically designed in Eq. (15). The system given in Eqs. 9–13 is coupled non-linear differential system and it is almost impossible to report exact solution. Therefore, the numerical solution is obtained by using numerical method named shooting method. To implement shooting method along with Runge-Kutta scheme the basic practice to write alternative first order system of differential equation is exercised as Eqs. (16)-(19). The results are obtained and provided in terms of graphical and tabular trends. The Figs. 1–6 are plotted to examine the rotatory magnetized flow field of Casson fluid model in the presence of suspended nanosized particles. In detail, the impact of Casson fluid parameter on both radial and tangential velocities is examined in a magnetized and non-magnetized flow field. Fig. 1 is plotted to examine the impact of Casson fluid parameter on radial velocity in magnetized and non-magnetized flow field. It is noticed that for higher values of Casson fluid parameter the radial velocity reflects decline nature. It is important to note that for magnetized flow regime the radial velocity decline significantly as compared to non-magnetized flow field. In the presence of applied magnetic field ( =γ 0.5) the Lorentz force actively participated and such force is resistive force as a result the rotatory Casson fluid flow faced resistance due to which the radial Casson fluid velocity reflects decline magnitude as compared to non-magnetized flow field that is the applied magnetic field is absent =γ( 0.0). The impact of Casson fluid parameter on tangential velocity profile is examined for both the magnetized and non-magnetized cases. The Fig. 2 is plotted in this direction. Similar observations are recorded as we did in case of Fig. 1 that is the tangential velocity shows decline curves for the positive values of Casson fluid parameter and such decline is significant in the presence of applied magnetic field ( =γ 0.5) as compared to non-magnetized case. The energy equation is taken in the presence of heat source and heat sink. The physical parameters appeared in this direction are named with heat generation parameter +H( ) and heat generation absorption parameter −H( ). The impact of both parameters namely, heat generation and heat absorption on Casson fluid temperature is examined and provided by means of Fig. 3. It is noticed that for higher values of heat
generation parameter the Casson fluid temperature enhances due to generation of heat energy in the rotatory fluid flow regime. On another hand, heat absorption parameter has opposite impact on temperature profile that is the Casson fluid temperature is decreasing function of heat absorption parameter. Fig. 4 depicts the influence of thermophoresis parameter on Casson fluid temperature. It is noticed that the Casson fluid temperature increases towards higher values of thermophoresis parameter. For higher values of thermophoresis the motion of particles from hotter region towards colder region increases due to which the thermal energy exchange increases as a results the Casson fluid temperature increases. Further it can be seen from Fig. 4 that the temperature reflects decline magnitude for magnetized flow field =γ( 0.5) as compared to non-magnetized flow field ( =γ 0.0). We know that the temperature is defined by average kinetic energy and in Figs. 1 and 2 it was concluded that the velocities shown decline values towards magnetic field flow field so that the average kinetic energy drops as a results the temperature reduces in a magnetized flow field. The impact of Brownian motion parameter and Lewis number on Casson fluid concentration is examined and offered via Figs. 5 and 6 respectively. To be more specific, from Fig. 5 it is noticed that the Casson fluid concentration is decreasing function of positive values of Brownian motion parameter. The positive values of Brownian motion parameter is the cause of increment in Brownian force to drag Casson fluid particles towards opposite direction of gradient of concentration and hence homogeneity is generated in nanofluid. The effect of Lewis number on Casson fluid concentration is tested and provided by way of Fig. 6. It is observed that the Casson fluid concentration reflects decline magnitude towards higher values of Lewis number. Both Figs. 5 and 6 are plotted for magnetized flow field.

sections.heading: 6. Conclusion
sections.text:
The non-Newtonian magnetized rotatory fluid flow over a rigid disk is investigated in the presence of suspended nanosized particles. The developed mathematical equations are solved by shooting method along with Runge-Kutta algorithm. The key observations are itemized as follows:
• The velocities which includes both radial and tangential are decreasing function of Casson fluid parameter. • The fluid velocities reflects significant decline magnitude in a magnetized flow field as compared to non-magnetized flow field. • The fluid temperature shows an inciting values for heat generation parameter. • The fluid temperature is decreasing function of heat absorption parameter. • The fluid temperature reflects higher values towards positive thermophoresis parameter. • The fluid concentration shows same variation towards Brownian motion parameter and Lewis number. Conflicts of interest
Author has no conflict of interest at this stage.

referenceMentions.context: The magnetized flow field properties for boundary layer fluid flow subject to stretched surface was investigated by Pavlov [14].
Chakrabarti and Gupta [15] extended the work presented in Ref.
[16] considered interaction of the magnetic field with the power-law fluid.
To achieve the equivalent system we have used the following set of variables [48].
[48] subject to numerical values of both local Nusselt number and local Sherwood number.

metadata.abstractText: In this paper, the rotatory non-Newtonian fluid flow subject to rigid disk is debated. The Casson fluid is used as a non-Newtonian fluid model and the fluid is equipped above the rigid disk. The rotatory flow field is interacted with an applied magnetic field. The heat transfer aspects are evaluated in the presence of heat source/sink. Further, the nanosized particles are suspended in the flow regime. The physical statement is mathematically controlled in terms of partial differential equations. The numerical method named shooting method is utilized in this analysis. The involved flow controlling parameters includes the Casson fluid parameter, magnetic field parameter, heat generation parameter, heat absorption parameter, thermophoresis parameter, Brownian motion parameter and Lewis number. The impact of these parameters are examined on the Casson fluid velocities, temperature and concentration. It is noticed that the both radial and tangential velocities are supressed in the magnetized rotatory flow field as compared to nonmagnetized rotatory flow field. The Casson fluid temperature enhances towards higher values of thermophoresis and heat generation parameters. The results are compared with an existing work which yields the surety of adopted computational algorithm.
metadata.creator: Elsevier
